channel.name: How to use runtime tables correctly

messages.content:
So I have got this runtime table working which is taken directly from the test `pickles_test_optional_gates.ml`https://github.com/NetZeroOrg/V2/blob/develop/src/app/netzero/test_lookup.ml
and with this `run.ml` https://github.com/NetZeroOrg/V2/blob/develop/src/app/netzero/run.ml. I am able to run the tests from what I understand shouldn't I be able to add values to this table and query it. As from the mina book:
> runtime tables are tables whose contents are determined at proving time, to be used for array accesses to data from the witness. Also called dynamic tables in other projects.
So how do I update the table which I am adding with this
```
add_plonk_constraint
 (AddRuntimeTableCfg
    { id = Int32.of_int_exn table_id
    ; first_column = Array.map ~f:Field.Constant.of_int first_column
    } ) ) ;
```
I also found this https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/blob/be5b2d8b6ebdb1bf3c581a75690dd657c046b48f/src/lib/crypto/kimchi_backend/common/tests/test_lookup_table_constraint_kind.ml#L188
But this just checks the `witness` and uses the `runtime_tables` from `compute_witness`  to get the data but there is not any proving operation here. 

So can someone explain to me how to use runtime tables correctly or if I am misunderstanding them as sort of "Dynamic tables in which you create dynamic lookup proofs"

messages.content: @Florian , can you provide some insights on this?

Runtimes arent fully exposed in o1js yet (I opened an [issue](https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/2079) for it last week) - the only thing to go off of is the pickles tests. Your understanding is correct, but I would have to look at the implmenation myself to tell you how to use them in OCaml

embeds.title: Make runtime tables available to o1js · Issue #2079 · o1-labs/o1js
embeds.description: Describe the feature or improvement Pickles and Kimchi both support runtime tables. Runtime tables give us access to dynamic (not hard coded) values at proving time. Unlike static lookup tables (wh...

messages.content: You have to use the lookup constraint to load values into the table
Can you reference to some code here?

hey @Florian any updates on how do I dynamically add data to runtime tables  as in all examples what we do 
```
let runtime_lt_data =
  let runtime_table_ids =
    let ids =
      List.init max_runtime_lt_n ~f:(fun _ -> 1 + Random.State.int state 100)
    in
    (* making sure they're all unique *)
    Int.Set.to_array (Int.Set.of_list ids)
  in

  Array.map runtime_table_ids ~f:(fun table_id ->
      let max_table_size = 1 + Random.State.int state 1000000 in
      let first_column =
        Int.Set.to_array
          (Int.Set.of_list
             (List.init max_table_size ~f:(fun _ ->
                  1 + Random.State.int state (max_table_size * 4) ) ) )
      in
      let table_size = Array.length first_column in
      let second_column =
        Array.init table_size ~f:(fun _ -> Random.State.int state 1_000_000)
      in
      (table_id, first_column, second_column) )
```
then I add the runtime table data to my main as:

```
let main_runtime_table_cfg () =
  Array.iter runtime_lt_data ~f:(fun (table_id, first_column, _) ->
      add_plonk_constraint
        (AddRuntimeTableCfg
           { id = Int32.of_int_exn table_id
           ; first_column = Array.map ~f:Field.Constant.of_int first_column
           } ) ) ;
  Array.iter runtime_lookups ~f:(fun (table_id, (k1, v1), (k2, v2), (k3, v3)) ->
      add_plonk_constraint
        (Lookup
           { w0 = fresh_int table_id
           ; w1 = fresh_int k1
           ; w2 = fresh_int v1
           ; w3 = fresh_int k2
           ; w4 = fresh_int v2
           ; w5 = fresh_int k3
           ; w6 = fresh_int v3
           } ) )
```
But here I add a constraint meaning if I have to add more data I would have to recompile my circuit again here is my main run function:
```

let () =
  let feature_flag =
    Plonk_types.Features.{ none_bool with lookup = true; runtime_tables = true }
  in
  let tag, _cache_handle, proof, Pickles.Proof.[ lkproof ] =
    time "compile" (fun () ->
        Pickles.compile ~public_input:(Pickles.Inductive_rule.Input Typ.unit)
          ~override_wrap_domain:Pickles_base.Proofs_verified.N1
          ~auxiliary_typ:Typ.unit
          ~branches:(module Nat.N1)
          ~max_proofs_verified:(module Nat.N2)
          ~name:"Lookup table runtime"
          ~choices:(fun ~self:_ ->
            [ { identifier = "main"
              ; prevs = []
              ; feature_flags = feature_flag
              ; main =
                  (fun _ ->
                    Test_lookup.main_runtime_table_cfg () ;
                    { previous_proof_statements = []
                    ; public_output = ()
                    ; auxiliary_output = ()
                    } )
              }
            ] )
          () )
  in
```

> But here I add a constraint meaning if I have to add more data I would have to recompile my circuit again here is my main run function:

Yes, you do have to know in advance how much data you want ot allocate
Yes but they aren’t dynamic are they? I read the theory looked at the source code I just don’t understand their is need then what makes them different from fixedlts

You will need to know how much size to allocate in advance, but the usage is dynamic as in you dont need to hardcode your values at compile time (which is what you have to do without runtime tables) - hope that makes sense! They are also now available in o1js
okay are there any examples in how to use them in circuits in o1js thanks!

messages.content: @utkarshdagoat I'm curious if you had a chance to try the new lookup table feature in JS.  If you have any feedback about DevX, I'd love to hear it!

Hey So I did but not extensively because they did not fit the use case but I think it can  have a better filling api if that makes sense something. Also some examples with full actions i.e (filling + lookup gates) would be better  and documentation on their capabilities and use case would be a nice plus
